Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 32nd IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The grant supports travel for graduate and undergraduate students to attend the 32nd IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME 2016), in Raleigh, North Carolina on October 2-10, 2016, which is the main international conference in this Software Engineering research area. The funds are to increase participation of qualified US-based students with attention to for underrepresented groups. The grant gives students an opportunity to engage in technical, professional, and social components of the meeting, which will contribute to their formation as researchers in the field, will provide them with feedback about their work, and will create and strengthen collaborations. It will help build the next generation of researchers in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twelve Ph.D. students from eleven U.S. universities, spread across eleven U.S. states were supported through this grant to attend the 32nd IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME 2016). Several of the students supported are part of a minority group: one student with disabilities, two female students, one Hispanic/Latino student, and one African American student were supported. Both female students had never attended ICSME or its co-located events before. The grant therefore allowed the increase of female participation in the software maintenance and evolution research community. Also, seven out of the twelve supported students are U.S. citizens, five of which had never attended ICSME or co-located events before.

The grant covered most of the students’ travel expenses to attend the ICSME 2016 conference and allowed them to present their papers. All awarded students authored and presented at least one paper at ICSME and its co-located events. Overall, this award allowed the presentation and publication of: 3 full papers in the Main Research Track at ICSME’16, 2 full papers in the Industry Track at ICSME’16, 1 paper in the Early Research Achievements Track at ICSME’16, 1 paper in the Tools Track at ICSME’16, 1 paper in the Doctoral Symposium Track at ICSME’16, 1 Technical Briefing at ICSME’16, 1 paper at the Eighth International Workshop on Managing Technical Debt (MTD’16 – co-located with ICSME’16), 1 tool paper at the Fourth IEEE Working Conference on Software Visualization (VISSOFT’16 - co-located with ICSME’16), 1 engineering paper at the 16th IEEE International Working Conference on Source Code Analysis and Manipulation (SCAM’16 - co-located with ICSME’16).

The award benefitted the ICSME and software engineering research community at large by allowing the work summarized in the papers authored by the funded students to be disseminated to the ICSME’16 community and by enlarging the ICSME community and its future generation of organizers and researchers (seven out of the twelve students funded had never attended ICSME or its co-located events before). The grant also supported the research community by increasing the participation of minorities in this conference, including students with disabilities, women, Hispanic/Latino students, and African-American students.

The grant also contributed towards the training, professional development, and the fostering of professional networks of the supported graduate students by allowing them to attend the research presentations at the conference and interact with other researchers and practitioners in the field.


Last Modified: 08/28/2017
Modified by: Sonia C Haiduc
